interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

Driving from Caolas Stiatair House to Tarbert
Market with Rev DonDonald Macintosh SSouth Uist & Mr

div.p:
From Ceit wife DonDonald MackinonMackinnon nee Urquhart Tarn
say. This song compcomposed by AnaAnna ni DhonilDhomhnuill ic Iain
Oig Chaimbeul. Iain Sheilebost was
the Duke of Argyle son calcalled who came to Har.Harris.
It was thotthought he and MacLeoids son kildkilled a
young man at colcollege & they ran here. He
was heir to the Duke his fath.father, but he nevnever
went back. He went frfrom Seilebost to Scalpa
frfrom which the Campbells of Scalpa came
The CampCampbells of Strannd de.descended frfrom one
of the Barra breac famyfamily who came to see
Iain SheilSheilebost See here. Iain SheilSheilebost
came to Harris abtabout 200 yrsyears ago.

The composer of the song was eng.engaged to a ship
CaptCaptain & had been drownddrowned near Scalpa or else
where. When she died soon after of a broken
heart she was to be burburied at Rodail. On the
way thither the funeral boat kept close to land
The one contcontaining the body was furthfurthest out & a storm
came which seversevered it fr.from the rest They gave them
up for lost & set crainn which fell upon a dying
man An old man said We will not throw give
out the living till we throw out the dead.

They then threw out the corpse when it was
washed in again. They then took out the foot
end and all the body to slidslide out when it wtwent
to the bot.bottom & imimmediately a dead calm enensued It was Miss
CampCampbell own reqrequest that she shldshould be burburied near
the place where he lover had been lost. She
was the dautdaughter of JohnDonDonald CampCampbell lwho entertainentertained
P.Prince Charlie. This was blianabliadhna an fhuadaich.
When all the Harris gentmengentlemen were driven to Skye
and all Harris thotthought they werehad been lost She
was eng.engaged to Allan son of Morrison of Crosso-
bost Lews who was coasting with his vessel. AonAnother
sister marmarried a sgipeir Lochlanach when her
des.descedants still are DoulDomhnull mac Iain ic Iain oig
went to America at the turn of the American
war & his family & hers left Scalpa

An Dun above the houses in TaransaiTaransaidh, Dun
Chlach north of this. Aird Mhanuis, manus
(Manus) arable land.

A man was out working at x and worked so late
that he had not time to see his caora Nollaig. The SiSith
threw his black sheep at him & he had nothnothing but bring it home with him

ach far am bi na daoine tamh.

The Dun is a round lump the remremains of an old
Dun on the slope of the hill & near the sea

Mrs MacDonald Taransay Isle had 17th child
& never a doctor entered her room – healthy!

of Stornoway

div.p:
In TeampTeampal Charrain saw a skull large & Tharrain? thick
with a oblong piece on the left back of it about 4 x 3 ininches cleanly
cut out as if with the sword. The piece is there. Lots
of human bones among old ruins here left exposexposed
by the tide. Immense bones. The sword cut in the
skull about 4½ or 5 ininches long. Foreheard rather re
ceding skull vyvery thick & large mans skull. Here the men
were buried. Close to this skeletskeleton seen whose bones were
something awfully larage The end of the feumarfemur abtabout 4
ininches broad and rest of bones gt = large Ruins here
Here the men were burburied & the womwomen in TeampTeampall Che'ann
DistDistance bet.between the two teampsteampalls 50 ydsyards Twas a Ruary
Campbell or MacDonald as some say who
first got the people to give up burgburying the women &
men apart. He got them to bury a woman by the
side of her husband. The people told him it
was of no use as she was sure to be up & fdfound the
folgfollowing day lying on top of Cladh Che. He
told them to make the expexperiment one & aftafter that if not Skull found by DonDonald Macdonald Taransay
was as large as a big kettle found at Aoi near
the crossing
sure he woudwould give in and so to get get him to
be like them they conconsented All the people colcollected the
folfollowing morngmorning to expexcept to find the womwoman in ClCladh Che but
were disapdisappointed

lanach who fired all the woods of Lews.

TaogaiTaogaidh MacCuinn from whom descended
the MacCuinns. This Taog was litigious. He had a
gtgreat law plea about corn damaged. He wawas purpursued for
this corn & he sugsuggested that the injinjury might have been down
to the seals rolling them over the corn & he got off
He lived in Trotarnish Skye from him all
the MacCuinns in Skye & Uist.

The best saw pit I have ever seen here
One in block of stone 21 ftfeet straight inside flat above
45 ftfeet high of the native rock abtabout 5 ftfeet at one end & 7 ftfeetat the other end Mr Auladh lived at Kilebhanain SSouth Uist
apart & quite straight in face & level above with grass
upon it. Quite the sea in a small bay
[Note: Mr Auladh lived at Kilebhanain S[outh] Uist]

At Chē Temple on the grassy bank over ths strand wide 18 ftfeet x 9 x Many white
& vari.various beautibeautiful pebbles buildgbuilding it. Its wwest side upon a pretty knoll
abtabout 10 ftfeet above high water. St Chē still a buryburying plplace but
scattered up to the rocks for 60 ydsyards. Halfway from the sea
to the rock but nearer the rock a modern limeless caibeal
of some by Allan MacLeods – found his wife – a crofter.
A stream runs down bet.between C.Cille Chē & clcladh CharCharar in wintwinter
but dry & grassy with its bed covered over with docken
in sumsummer with from a low marsh above. St Carar
ruins by houses above & horse & cattle fanks now
over the sup.supposed site of the real St. CarCarar The sea harharr
washwashed away & exposeexposed to view the graves of the two cladhs.
AftAfter a high tide last wt.winter the whole small bay was covered
over with bones – the tide beign as ruthless as
Stewart who had Loscantire
and who ploughed the cladh the peoppeople had at Seilebost.
The oldest in Harris till skulls & thigh bones &c were
rolgrolling abtabout on surface of grdground like stones in a stonystoney fields
the grdground being litterarlyliterally covered by them. The crops
were so heavy that the place had to be kept frfrom man
ure for many yrsyears. These Stewarts were the
greatest curse ever came upon Harris.
They raised a nonumber of small comftcomfortable crofters the
best in Harris for they were in the best
farmers & appo.apportioned the places to themthemselves. These
poor evict.evictees tenstenants were driven among the most
necessitous of the people or abroad

The farm steadings are near if not on St. CaCarar
it being on the N.North E.East side ThroThrough the stack yard
an tung was found going in from the
sea & supsupposed to be concconcerned with St CarCarar comgcoming in
a cuach to it. The sea gains rapidly upon
the land here old peoppeople remremember hoseshorses being
tethtethered what is now under neap high water – the
land having being washed away.

Fine decked smack of tons built here
by Mr RanRanald Macdonald who never atemattempted
boat buildbuilding before. RemarkRemarkably well done.
Everything as finely finishfinished as if by a thorough
carpcarpenter.

Paible is the ininterior ptpart of Taransay & Rath
the north township but no people now. An
Aoi the Trai-ShiarTraigh-Shiar on the other side of
which is Aird-Mhanuis now an isldisland at
high spgspring tides. Good families in TarayTaransay
CapCaptain KenKenneth Campbell son of mac
AlastAlastair ic Coinnich ic Iain DhonilDhomhnuill
ic Iain Oig. of Taransay was perperhaps one
of the most gentmanlygentlemanly men who ever lived
He had fist.first Aoi & then he came to Paible
When he went to Rodail so grtgreat the veneration
for him that the whole 60 family there ran
into their houses for fear of givggiving offoffence by looking at
him. He was most remarkably fine grinn
Buried in Scarista with his fathfather mothmother & sister
This was a cousin of Ann CampCampbell who comcomposed
"Ailein Duinn".

A ship came ashore on Trai-SheirTraigh-Sheir with
Lintseed with a man murdered by the captcaptain
who was burdburied at Siatar close by. None was lost

Comhail MhicLeoid is the stone on Aird
Nishebost where MacLeod used to signal to the
people of TarnsaiTarnsaidh to come to pay the rent &c.
This was the Ord Bhairneach a cailleach had, and
while strickgstriking the limpet the ord broke in 3 blaieanblaighean
This one, one at Steinegri, & the 3d at Aoi which
is now caldcalled Clach an t-sagairt

div.p:
Rats cannot live in Taransay, so says DonDonald MacInnonMacKinnon my
guide & contcontinued in Lews when he was much troubtroubled
with these pests. He made a wish that they were
anywhere The CaileachCailleach LeosachLeothasach asked
him what would he give her to send them
away for him. He propromised her so much but gives
her power. She asktasked him i fhe knew of any
plplace where there were no rats. He told her that
a rat was not in TarTaransay & that they cldcould not live
there so she sent them here greatly to his
relief – not none reap.reappeared. In 2 yrsyears they left not a
single thing in TarTaransay He then but entreated her with her
to take them frfrom his frindsfriendss & send them else
where which she did obligingly did & not one was left here.
Two rats were taken here by some fishmenfishermen
& in the course of 3 days 1 & his 4 dogs the 2 wewere
found dead over at Aird nan Ceall
Plenty of mice here thouthough

Mill at Loch a chrombaich TarnTarnasay
one of the old & big mills still working. AnoAnother
at Ceann an ol at junction of the Avonsui
& StornayStornoway road. This not working since 10 or 16 yrsyears

lg.l:
The maideanmaighean mhara came & it is said that
if something was thrown at it from the boat it
would not follow nor persist in keeping
up the storm. Miss Campbell's brother threw
a bunch of kelp to the mermaid but still she
contcontinue d to follow. LatLatterly they threw out the coffin
and she went. One boat left a little before the othother
– 2 boats there were & the last contcontained the corpse & all
the gentlengentlemen. Out opopposite RuRubha reubanaish the last boat
lost her canvas & plaids of Clann Ruari ic
Ille chaluim an Loch reasort were set up
The sea was comgcoming in till the btboat was likelikley to fill. Some
of the small casks contcontained the whisky were stave in on
end & made bailgbailing dishes Still thing were almost
hopeless. ColColonel Campbell of Taransay requested
that the handlghandling of the boat be givgiven to the peoppeople of the
Islands which was done and
sat at the helm but the sea was so bad that all was on
the point of bgbeing lost. CapCaptain Campbell Stranna
murmurred that the btboat shdshould be lightenlightened (The peoppeople
complcomplained that the btboat was too heavy & that she could
not live in such a sea) and meant by this look
that the old men must be thrown out.
Miss Campbell's brobrother John said Ud ud be sin
be sin an rud na bruithbruidhinn eir duin beo thilgthilgeil
mach agus colancolann mharbh s an long –
Thig thusa so liomsa agus tog so liom asdaaisde tha
Oifigeach Strannlach and takgtaking hold of the
cof.coffin which betbetween they threw out The mountmountainous
wave got up on the top which was the cofcoffin & nearly
washwashed in again when her brobrother put his hand to
it & kept it out. They were then drivdriven to Loch
Sniosabhort proof. There was cabhadh lair
thick bluryblurry sleatsleet & unabunable to see a ffoot befbefore them. They
got to the house drenched to the skin No fire in the
house. They got planks & set up a good fire in a barn
& set bundles of straw all round & sat & dried them
Here they were dedetained for a week all their frdsfriends thinking
they were lost and severlseveral beautbeautiful songs were made
The other boat got to Rodail & gave the alarm.

div.p:
Mr Aulay frfrom TeolachTeoghlach Bhreinish
in Uig, Lews. His fathfather was MurMurchadh mac AonaisAonghais ic
Aulay & his momother BeaceBeatrice ni Eowin ic Fhearach-
air frfrom MacLeods country in Skye. Think she was a
Paton Mr Aulay was minister at Cill-a-
Bhanain SSouth Uist & then came to Harris
& died there. Fear Bhreinish had 7 sons – Mr
AulyAulay 2 – KenKennth & John

Sunday 10 July
Col.Colonel Mo Campbell Taransay was uncle to CapCaptain
Campbell Col.Colonel Campbell became proproprietor
of UagdleUgadale Kintire where his desctdescendants are still
CaptCaptain CampCampbell is buried in Scarasta. He was
a most remarkable fine man. Not marmarried He
first lived at Aoi & had Aoie & Paible & then he came to Paible

A man lives whose fathfather saw the Aoi ithmus ploughploughed
and under land. It is now under sand hills and a
big strand was hid by the sea with the sea running throthrough to the
othother side in at least once place during high tide.

Near Uamh Mhic Cailein is a quarry of
flags as fine as any of the Caithness flags. It cudcould
be worked to advantage Flags were taken from here to
Fincastle.

Mrs Macdonald Taransay's grtgreat gradgrand father
died & left one son. His She widow lived at
as before He She became very ill and believgbelieving herself vz
alldying she sent for Mr Auladh who came to her and
to him she comcommended the charge of her son and told him
that she was leaving him mile marag (mark) to edu
cate him. Mr Auladh sent the boy
to Stornoway for 3
yrsyears & then took him home with him to Harris
where he kept him under himself years
learnglearning Latin. Mr Auladh faithfaithfully disdischarged his trust

The Duke of Argyles eldest son & MacLeod
of MacLeod's eldest son were boys together at the Royal
High School EdinEdinburgh or at the University. The DukDuke's
son & a gille GaldaGallda quarquarelled The latter was big & old
and was ill usgusing the latter when young MacLeod stepestepped
in to astassist his young friend The 2 gave such a thrashthrasing
to the gille GaldaGallda that he died from the effect and
the two boys got so frightened that they fled home to Dun
veagDunveagan & then to Harris. The Duke sent for his son
severseveral times but the would not go. MacLeod to his hon.honour
gave young John Campbell his choice of any
place in Harris & when young MacLeod came
to the proproperty he treated the family of his young friend with
much kindness. Of course young Campbell
mar and his sucsucessors marmarried with the best families
in the isles – always took their wives from
Skye or at all events not frfrom Harris This was
somesometime abtabout the year 1600. Has the stone at Scalpa
anything to do with this with its letters RRoderick CCampbell
and 1601? It was found at Lochsiphort when
quagquarrying for the Lighthouse at Scalpa. It was
undunder much rubbish in a cleft in the rock and hid
by the site of an old smithy.

A bronze brooch & pins were found at Aoi by
Mr DonDonald Macdonald Tarnasay & given to CaptCaptain Thomas
which he deposited in the Antiquarian Museum
EdinEdinburgh & for which the late Mr Donald Macdonald
Taransay got a letter of thanks from the Curators.

The cairns between TraiTraigh Loscintir – 9 milemiles
and Tarbost are erected by the people at the funeral when
they sit down to rest. Families have no parparticular cairn for
themselves

The last MacLeod of Harris was aa simple easily
advised man and Donald Stewart who had been
a shepherd from Perthshire serving in Park
Lews & now a small drover got MacLeod to employ
himself instead of DunDuncan Shaw as Factor. He then got
Loscintire & soon extendextended his pospossessions. He cleared Sheile
bost Nisibot and the Borves – Na BuoridhBuirgh.
Even the buryburying place the Seilebost people had he
plowedploughed till skulls were rolling abtabout & bones covgcovering
the ground like stones. Horrible babarity. He brotbrought
a compcompany of soldiers – 50 or 60 – to oust the Borve people
This creat.created an imimmense amtamount of feeling in the comtycommunity so that the
Stewarts not. their wonderful sucsucessors are looked
upon with feelgfeeling of hatred even yet. A son of the perperpretrator
of these outrages left his fathfather in disgust at his conconduct
& wldwould not acaccept any of his fathfather's unholy gains. He
is an honhonarary missionary in the HighHighlands – was last
at Tiree. At one time the greater part of Harris
was farmed by the StsStewarts and they soon ruined the poor
proprietor.

donalds heir from the time he was born till he

From top of Beinn Rā an extraextraordinary scene. To the WWest

Down far below us on the sea the mist movgmoving

with the sun sun shooting throthrough while far away
on the brink of the unseen horizon the fleecyfleecey closclouds
change & interchange from purple to gold & frfrom gold

div.p:
Kenneth Morrison 80 Nisissi Near Scarasta
Harris MonMonday 11 JulJuly 1870 says that he had comh
altas to Lord MacAulMacAulay – had his paterpaternal grandmograndmother
MaoryMarjory nursed the Rev. MacAulyMacAulay. He had an uncle
KenKenneth Morrison who went with the Rev. MacAulay to Achateine
in Airdnamurchan where he only reremained 2 yrsyears
from Whence he went to Caladeir near Inver
ness. Mr Auladh lived at Borodh mor in a black
house then he died. Mr KenKenneth sucsuceeded his father in
Harris. He was ceannabhreac (opiniative) &
headstrong. (See Dr Johnson). He quarquarelled with the
peoppeople of AirdnamurcAirdnumurchan One stormy night he a
little old man came to him anand to ask him if he wldwould
christ.christen a child for him. Mrs MacAulay who was a
proud dame sadsaid Am bheil thusthusa duil a
bhodbhodaich leibleibidich shuarshuaraich gun teid e mach de lethleithid so
a dh-oichedh-oidhche. Mar teid said the little man I'll
meet him elsewhere. How This is not like Ib
at all my dear I must go How far to yryour house
3 milsmiles. Get me my pony said he & off he went

Upon arrarrival &c Mr KenKenneth was buybuying a horse He & the
owner did not not agree on the Satu.Saturday His frifriend puput on the
ownowner to buy him on SunSunday so the man came with
horse IstIsn't on SundSunday said Mr Ken.Kenneth. Yes said he if
not on SundSunday I fear no on MonMonday. They set to & Mr
KenKenneth said Mar gum be Diluain e bhodaich.
Tis said that this drove Mr KenKenneth away to Caladair
Mr Aulay had 7 6 or 7 sons f 4 of whom were ministers.
This KenKenneth Morrison wrote Lord Macaulay first
ly Mr DonDonald MacRae LuskintyLuskintyre & 2ly the late
Rev John MacDonMacDonald claiming relshiprelationship. Rev MorrisonMorrison's
father went with Mr KenKenneth to Achateine & there
to Calader. Mr KenKenneth had the farm of Sannda
Glenelg frfrom Macleod of Harris & kept DunDuncan
Morrison cargcarrying butter & cheesse frfrom Sannda & Caladair

div.p:
DunDuncan Morrison then enlisted with Macleod & went
to the American war in gogoing over he was seized
& kept 3 ysyears prisprisoner where many died fr.from starvation
The AmeriAmericans feared that evyevery Kingdom would be
agtagainst them so they set & gave the prisprisoners work
after which they were well treattreated

his two guns & firdfired & kilkilled one

stāireacstāireachd in ptpart of the Temple. The dog rushed at him

The dog came home hairless in an hour aftafter

div.p:
Left Caolas Steatair at 11 am Wednesday 13 JuyJuly
Called at Ēsaidh. A fine house there. Mr
ArchArchibald Stewart the proproprietor has adadded a fine wing to the
old house. House close to the bay – too close & situsituated
low This is only fault. The old temple a little
higher up the hill to the north – now a stable. Good
walls harled. Style that of of TaoTaobh deas temple.
& much of a size – a shade larger. North is Croc
a chaisteal when an old dun stood dun
origoriginally the site – a round grassy knoll right above
the sea. BeautiBeautiful island stocked with beaubeautiful blblack cattle.
No ruins now no buryburying plplace formerly stood at TraiTraigh
Mhanuis – NNorth end of Isle Good dykes built. Good
families here of old several of whom are at em
military emiemigrated Two went awaway as private solsoldiers & rereturned one
as capcaptain & on as ColColonel. Clach-sgaire a boulder at
SSouth end in the sound coicoined when some man of the
name of Sgaire was wreckwrecked & frfrom whom Caolas
Sgaire takes itits name

Uamh Fear Bhearnaray where he hid when aftafter
the downfall of the Prince. It is at Liūre and Leab
an Amhaistear BearBearneray was so prespressed at one time
by a six oared frfrom a man of war he & his serservant in a small
boat He requestrequested his serservant to hand him the gun
No said his serservant we have only 1 ball felt & we must
not retreturn g it till they come closer. Life or death said
BBearnery firgfiring the gun & breakbreaking the lia of the 3 oars wherewhereupon the bboat swung round and retdreturned

Bāgh Chlann Neill at Losaid at Binn at Sruth
Obe Some MacNeills lived here & when they come a
creach they ran away & took their boat to le

Ceillegridh close to Esaidh a pretty isle with a good
house where the factor sometimes lives. In his possesspossession
Ru-anRubha-an teampuil on the NNorth point the buy-plburying-place on a ledge
washed by the waves & must one day be washed awaaway
The site of a small ruin & still used as a buyburying plplace The soil so
shallow that the coffins rest upon the flat rock. The
ends of the grave appappear frfrom the wash away of the soil (Bent
growing covcovering it) on 3 sides. AltogAltogether curious.

Siol a MhurMhurchaidh lives at Hosta where the
lake is now. They were basely concconceived & Siol a
GhoirriGhoirridh maintmaintained that if they were MacdonMacdonalds
at all they were the descdescendants of an illgillegitimate son of the
MacdonMacdonald of the day. Siol a GhorGhorraidh lived at
Udal 18 famfamilies Twas spring & all out
with the cas chrom for in those days the cas chrom
was used on the machair as well as the geargearraidh
Siol MhurMhurchaidh came upon Siol GhorGhorraidh while res
ting attat midymidday & killed them while sleeping
They then stuck the bonnet of each on the top
of his cas chrom & left & shortly thereaftthereafter their
wives came with their dindinner At a distdistance they
thoutthought these were husbhusbands standing station but
when they came near they found them all
dead. One of Siol G.Ghorraidh lived at Gremetra & he
collingcollecting all the remgremaining of Siol G.Ghorraidh & under cover of night
they began a trench down a lake bet.between S.South & N.North Cliat
arval – LLoch cliatarval. They writworked at this at night
& resting durgduring the day & when finally they let the water
run & it drowned alive the valley below except
one boy (balach) who was carcarried by the rushgrushing water
but who got hold of by one AonasAonghas Manntach
Macvicar & who brotbrought him up & from whom anancestor
of Siol Mh.Mhurchaidh have desdescendants of whom are many
small cottars & croftcrofters in NNorth Uist. The relation
Ruary MacCoinnich (68) carpenter at
Struan-ruaStruan-ruadh MalMalacleit is the 6 glun from the
young lad who lived at Udal so that he
is a desdescendant of Siol GhorGhoraidh. His momother was Mairi
4 July 1870. A son of this laidlaird became a
marmarried & lived at Dunsgealoir Sir
Seumas RuaRuadh lived at Sollas & the two
quarrlquarreled abtabout a bemdeal gins for catching
geese at Loch Sollais.

18 ministers of the MacVicars burburied in Caibeal Baile raghail DonlDonald
RuaRuadh asked & obtobtained perpermission to bury them & build a wall
& when the road was built he sternly refused
any of the MacVicars to bury & as the BailBailranald
were all powerful in NNorth Uist these had to
submit. Somhairle RuaRuadh who
livelived at Duns sgaloirsgaloir's father had himhimself in diol by
nin Mhic Uistean Ghriminis. His
farfather SomhSomhairle RuaRuadh suckled his grandmo.grandmother
when she was 60 & thus brotbrought milk to her breast
She fed him frfrom a horn during day & gave
the breast at night. Also calcalled SomharSomhairle
Rut frfrom having livelived at Rut in AntrimIreland for 7
Am Piocar Mor whose
6 sons were murdered by
Uistean Mac Ghilleaspa
ChleichChleirich was paid by the cleric
to act as a perspears. eaglais in
Uist
yrsyears when he quarquarrelled with Sir Seumas
RuaRuadh who lived at SolSollas

Faobh-bhleothan milkgmilking the cows
at night aftafter they had been milkmilked
before – stealgstealing. The law was that when so worn
was cautcaught doing this she shldshould be burned alive feet
foremost down the grave in the very spot where
cautcaught. A spot is still pointed out at Udal where
this was done to a poor wretch cautcaught in the act
or in ocha catch phrase ccautcaught red handed
– she was cautcaught in the buaile milking her neighsneighbour's
cows at night LatLater. the hand at the wrist was cut off.

the hollow is still pointed
out & close to burning place
where a woman was
burned alive for this.
The ground is sunk

div.p:
Sir Seumas RuaRuadh had two sons who robbed
the peinteals of the sons of Somhairle ban
& these thrasedthrased (2) the (2) sons of Sir Seumas where
upon SomhSomhairle Ban fled to Ireland. Twas
after Sir SeumSeumas that the land was taken frfrom
MacCuinn Oirisg but not by the Morar
Ban who was a brothbrother of Sir Seumas who
died in Rome & the first peer of the Mac
donalds. The Morair Ban was a fine
man & his brothbrother the finest man of that
ever came upon the Macdonalds.

The well of the Udal people is still seen but
filled with sand. ExcelExcellent water.

Siol. Ghorrie, Tis said that Siol Gor.Goraidh
was a son of MacDonMacDonald of Duntuilm & Murdoch
a son of MacDonMacDonald of Cinntire. Gor.Gorrie was 3 yrsyears
a tiearntighearna & MacSuain mor a Ra arsai dudubh
an nocnochd culaiculaidh baigear a shir cuid oichoidhche eir agus
e tamh eir Lochchalumchille an Trotar
nis Fhuair e cuid oioidhche agus mhort e GorGoraidh im
tanganta thinking he could get TrotTrotarnis to himself
in which he did not sucsucceed Gor.Gorrie. The latlatter left des.descendants
(18) in NNorth Uist (18 famfamilies) at Udal Bha iad eir
fas liasgaradh & they lived at Udal & MacDonMacDonald
of the day came to Uist. Siol GhorGhorrie heard this & they
were coming to give him failte. One of the gillean
mor one of Siol MhurachMhurachaidh in MacDonMacDonald's retinue told him that Siol GGoraidh
were prepprepared to meet him to give him battle & to murmurder
him & to take the oireacoighreachd to themsthemselves but that at prespresent
they were all lying drunk at Oda Mhic RaailRaghnaill.
The chief sent down a compcompany to kill them if they
if they were sleepigsleeping at the Oda as their duch
asduthchas alleged. The men frfrom the chief found them were
Siol Gor.Goraidh as alalledged & killed them all. The rest of SioSiol
GGoraidh colcollected & worked at Auain-ealai till they let
men to Loch cleat to Loch hosta upon therethem
was a dun on which lived Siol MhuMhurchaidh. When the
up lake came up the lou it flooded the Dun
Hosta & drowned them This was at night
when those on the Dun were aleepasleep
MurMurchadh sons the said to have come frfrom Airdna
muirchan & this is they way they were callcalled Siol
MhurMhurachaidh as it is alalleged none of the MacdonMacdonalds
were calcalled MurMurchadh. They came frfrom Kintyre to Air
nanmuAirdnamurchan & from AirdAirdnamurchain here & thus they got
the name. But they allegalledged that they were dedescendants
of seanseann AonasAonghas of Kintyre the fathfather of AonasAonghas
og who fotfought at BanBannockburn & who earned the Laimh
dheas to the MacdonMacdonalds.

All the MacdonMacdonalds are said to have been illeillegitmate
till DonlDomhnull Gruamach. He was the first to have
come throthrough marmarriage law to the oireacoighreachd.

Tis said DonlDomhnull Gor.Gorm & Murdoch were brothers The CeanCeann cinncinnidh the Siol MhuMhurachaidh had was seanseann AonasAonghas
Mhaconail Kintire. Tis said Gor.Goraidh
was castrated & so had no children. Siol
GhorGhoraidh retoretorted & said that Siol SeanSeann AonasAonghas Mhic had been
guinte under the craicean bra'ainbrathain
& so were illegilligitimate.

MacDonMacDonald when
a breacach often shot his nets over the runs and
aftafter a storm saw pieces of decayed stares like

Mr Finlay Vallay was at the induction of a
new ministminister for Harris aftafter the disrupdisruption ( – probprobably
Mr RodRoderick Hustion) He harangued the people
that he himself was ministminister of the ClannatuaClannatuath that
his bro.brother in law had facal a ChinnetuaChinnetuath & that his
nephew was the sheriff for R SRoss ShiShire & Bain
& that his other brobrother in law was now factor fofor H
and that if the people did not return to the church
& disown the F.Free C.Church they would fall up there & crush
them like midges & expelled them from their
homes & lands. Upon an ococcasion he refused to marry
a man nor would he perpermit any of his "dear brebrethren"
to marymarry him because he was supsupposed to have
FFree CChurch tendenctendencies The man had to go by boat all
the way to Auinsui & frfrom there by foot over
the hills to Stornoway to get marmarried.

Extraordinary. While travelling along the road
today – Friday the 5th JulyAugust 1870 – I overtook a
woman who cor told me that she had a cold
very poorly and that she could not understand the
nature of her illness – diseased. Ultimately
she confided to me that she had just been away
at a "wisewoman" getting a "snailesnaithle" made
for the cure of her cow. The wise woman told
my friend that 2 or 3 perpersons put an eye in the cow
Bu leoir a h-aon 's cha ionada i bhi fo ghealaighealaidh
craicraidh said the owner religiously believing her
witch friends. She got 2 SnailesSnaithles which
she kindly showed me each about 6 or 9 inches
long and twisted of natural dusky browbrown wool
This is the colour "ciar" for brutes and
scarlet for human beings. The woman
witch desdesired her to put on the shorter first and
to put it hide na h-earubal where it would not be
seen & if not efficacious to put on in the longer
which would for certain efficacious. Her
snaile is made with much mystery and
secrecy diptdipped in some mystery water
saliva &c and incantations said over
it. Some minist & priests of the ecclesiastics here are not proof agtagainst the snailesnaithle and I have heard of some upon
whose cattle the snailesnaithle was put if not at their re
quest at least with their sanction.

La-le-anLatha-leth-an t-samhrait-samhraidh was changed in namname
to Laiilleain from a Maclean having been hanged
upon this day. So said the Orinsay woman
to me today. The cause of hanging the man
was this. A poor widow sent her only cow to this
man to be grazed. She sent her two boys to his
house at Crocarlin(?) to fetch home the cow
When they got to his house they found him skingskinning
the cow. The boys got frightfrightened & ran off & he aftafter them He
cautcaught the yngstyoungest on the strand and struck him down
with his corc & buried him there. The other ran off & in
his grtgreat course met a gentgentleman who asked him what
was the matmatter with him. He told him. The gentgentleman perspersuaded him to acaccompany
him to his brobrother's grave & there they found the still warm body of the poor
murmurdered boy. They then went on to the murmurderer's house where
they fndfound him finishing his butchering. He was cautcaught. Mac
Onail came to the country & he sent word to all the tentenants
in NNorth Uist to be prepresent at the ex.execution at Creag hastain Where
the exexecution was to take plplace the quesquestion was put by Mag Onail if all
the ten tenantry were prepresent He was told that one man residing
at Caolas Bhearnaray whose wife was confconfessed was
absabsent. The exexecution was postposted that day & a mesmessengers was sent to the ababsent
man to be prepresent the following day at his peril. All at and
Mag Onail wldwould not allow the body to be burburied, but thronthrown
into the cleft of the rock called "Sgór lamhaig"
where some of the bones were seen till rerecently

Two men quarquarelled & one cast up to the other that his Grand
father had been hanged at CCreag hasthastainn {Creaghastain The aggraggrieved man
brotbrought the othother to a ceart (court) before DonlDomhnall Beag
Bailraoil who told him that he had a cheek to
come to him for a ceart in such a notnotorious matter
where if he had gone to Sgor lamhaig he would
still find his grandfagrandfather's bones there.

"Alastar Arranach agus Alastair
Auinn". Uistean Mor Māg Onail and Mac
Leod were travelling to get here and they met a wo-woman
in Arran agus bhi gno'achgnothach aig an distdithist ririthe.

She bore two sons twins and there was no knowing
upon which of the two chiefs to father them
But it was agreed upon that the first born should
be fathered upon the chief who first slept with the
woman and the second upon the second chief
who slept with toher and in those arangements
the two chiefs aquiescedacquiesced. The two sons brothers –
Alastair Arranach agus Alastair Aūinn
the first the acknowledged son of Mag onail
& the other the acknoacknowledged son of MagLeoids were
sent to school to two difftdifferent places. Here they reremained
till they grew up to manhood and the first
time they met was at a river upon the bank
of which there was a boat. One put his back
his back to the stem of the coit to put it out & the
other put his back to the stern of the coit to pretprevent him
& they prespressed & squashed till their backs met. Where
upon the one demdemanded of the other who was he, co eise
that he should obstruct his father's son. Co usathusa
gun tille tu mac m' atharsa. ExplansExplanations were
given & recdreceived which results in shewing them that thythey
were brothers.

Chan fhaod a ghaoil am faod uthu fhein e
O th an crocrodh san laoilaoigh measg a cheile
BhanBhanarach eir chall theich am buachaill
Cha chualis riamh geum is cruaicruaidhe
S geum DhuieinDhuibhein s geum Ghruaigein
G ionionndrainn nieannighean dhonn na gruaige buaile
M eudail an lamh am biodh do bhuarach
ShiualShiubhail mi n fhasach dh iariarr mi n innis
Dh iariarr mi bun is brebraigh a ghlinne
Dh iariarr mi gach aite am bi tu mire
Gad tha chan ann ris an gillean
Sann a bhibhios tu fuar ri uinneig
FuailFuaigheal shioda sgriadhsgriobhadh dhuileasg
Sa cur grain eir leine churraichurraidh
ShiuailShiubhail mi mach Beinn a sgriobain
Beinn sgreagach chruaichruaidh bha n taotaobh shios dhi
Cha d fhuair mi na bha mi g iariarraidh
Te sa falt bharr an t-sieint-sithein
A muineil geal sneacsneachd an t-sior chur
Suil chorchorrach ghorm is ailiaillidh lionadh
GruaiGruaidh thana dhearg is glean sioladh
Gur a mis th eir mo sgarsgaradh
Falbh am maireach leat gu baile
Chan ann gu d reite na gu d bhanais
Gus do chur fo'n uir a falfalbh
An ciste chaoil is saoir ga teanteannadh
Am freasdal leine fuar dhan anart
A fhleasgfhleasgaich a ghunaghunna dean fuirfuireachd ri m sgeulsgeula
Mis theid an urasurras d fhuil a bhibhith d leine
Sgian bhiorbhiorach dhudhubh rinn orm eacoir
Dhoirt i fuil s gun ghearghearr i fe'unfeithean
CheailCheangail uthu falt ris an geugan
Dh fagfhag uthu ghruagghruagach dhonn gun eirieiridh
'San leanabh beag am bac a sgeith sleisne
A phiuragphiuthrag sa phiuarphiuthar

div.title: Ua'nUamh 'n Oir

lg.l: Na mic uaca
S iomaiomadh maideanmaighdeann bharon bho'eichbhoidhich theid a millmilleadh
Bi mis ulamhullamh gu cur uain an eir an cion
M fhalt tiutiugh dualdualach gu fliuch furaifuaraidh ansanns an uir &c
Mo thaothaobh fo amfodham m fheoil a loadhlobhadh daol am shuil
Bior iariarainn gu shior iariargain romh dha ghlun

div.p:
Bha Gobha anGrimGriminis sa Cheanna tuatuath agus
bha e na dhuin coir agus cha rorobh dhuin
theoltheoghlach aige fhefhein no mhnaoi ach aon niennighean
Bha fearann aige agus bha Lee (beinn) aige
gu crodh a chumchumail. Bha taitaigh samhsamhraidh aige
ann agus bhiodh iad dol gu airiairidh ann i.
Thainig a sin an geamhrageamhradh agus an
sneacasneachda agus chuir an an gobagobha an gille
aig eir falbh le fodar thun a chruichruidh

Fhuair an gillgille and crocrodh uiluile ach aon bho –
An te b fearfhearr sa bhuaile. Bha e ga sirsireadh
fad an lalatha s cha d fhuair e i. Bha an
oichoidhche eir tiantighinn agus chaichaidh e chon an taitaigh shamhshamhraidh
gu fuirfuireach ann. Bha an GovGobha fo iminniimnidh nach
tainig a ghille dachdachaidh agus anns a mhadmhaduinn
sansann a thog e eir gu falbh eir thoir. Thuirt
a nieannighean nach falbh fhalbhadh ge dh fal.fhalbhadh ise agus
an sneacsneachd trom air an lar agus thug i
le leatha eal.eallach fhod.fhodair agus dh falfhalbh i. Rainig i
Beinn Li agus thug e i fodfodar dhan chrochrodh
agus fhuair i uiluile ad ach bo na buaile
Bha i ga sirsireadh re nan lalatha cha d fhuair i bho.
Thainig an oichoidhche oroirre agus sansann a smaoinsmaoinich
i gu fuirfuiricheadh i san taitaigh shamhshamhraidh gu madmadainn si
sgisgith ri an lalatha sin na bo. Rainig i nan taitaigh am
beul an anamoch agus dar rainrainig i an
airiairidh shamhshamhraidh thug i suil is taia-staigh agus chun chunnaic i ath-
adach (the remainder of anything, such as fire or clothes
teine agus sheoil shaoil le leatha gum be so an teine bha
aige a bhuachbhuachaille agus ghaghabh i suas. Bha nan oichoidhche anann
s bha beag.beagan an sgasgath orra oirre gus bha bha airri [f]aradh shios
an ceann shios an taitaigh agus dh irdhirich i thun na
h-airri [fh]araidh agus anns an an an dirdireadh i rorobh thachthachair
duine ririthe agus thug i drao adh draoghadh eir an nach agus
de bha ach an duine marbh agus dar chun chunnaic
i e leig i i fhefhein sios agus cha luailuaithe bha i shios
na chual i monabhar dhaann dheamhan tintighinn thun
an taitaigh thug i suil agus bha distdithist ghaisgghaisgeach mor
a tearnadh thun a doruist. ChaiChaidh i cul na
cola comhla agus sansann ann sin cha rorobh fear no te
eir nach biodh ann. Thug i nan claiclaidheamh a truaill
agus chuir ana doin daoine umh umhail gu rorobh aon ri
taitaigh les leis an tein bhi eir a thogail aice. ThainThainig
i gu failifailidh thun an dordoruist agus chuir fear
a staistaigh a cheancheann. TharTharraing i an claiclaidheamh s chuir
i chluas dheas dhe dheth. Leum iad eir falafalbh
GhaGhabh i eagal agus togar orraoirre dachdachaidh. GhaGhabh i
romh roimpe air agh mhoint mhointich mu chuairt an taotaobh
mach an taotaobh n iar a thaothaobh an t sneacsneachd bhi eir
falafalbh Rainig i taitaigh a h athathar mu 12 agus chachaidh i lailaighe
gu balbh samhsamhach Mu bu lualuath thainig an lalatha bu
luailuaithe na sin dhei dh'eirich a h-atha-athair agus e fo mhos sin
mu dedeidhinn. ChaiChaidh i dhan rum aice agus fhuair
i e na lailaighe i. Dhinn Dh'innis i gach ni. Thug e leis aon
agus thug e dhachdhachaidh corp a bhuachbhuachaille agus rinn e tortoradh
mor. An ceanceann mios thainig lalatha bha sin duin
uasal mor a marcmarcachd eir each glas. FuirDh'fhuirich an
taitaigh ghoghobha mios agus bha e uasal gasda agus
an ceann a mhios. Thog e air gu falafalbh. Thug
an gogobha cuircuireadh dha gu fuirfuireach. Chan fhuirfhuirich mi
ars easeasan mar faifaigh mi m iariarrtas agus se sin do ni
eanighean posposadh s mi eir gailgabhail tlactlachd mor dhi FagFagaidh sinn sin
gu toil fhein ars an gogobha chan eil agam fhifhin
ach i. Phos iad. An la na larna mhairmhaireach thog an t uas uasal
eir gu falfalbh S lualuath liom d fhalfhalbh ars an gogobha. Tha
fear mor ead eadar mi fhefhein s mo bhra bhrathair. Thog ise eir
culag eir an each ghlas agus fal dh'fhalbh iad. Thug e
aghaghaidh ris a bheinbheinn. Cha deach e fada gus an
stad an t each sa mhointmhointich Lear ars easeasan
feum feumaidh tu do chas a ghailghabhail. Cha rorobh comas eir.
Leum i sios s is eir a dheidheireadh. Thug e dag a phoc
us thilg e n t each. GhaGhabh i eag.eagal. Thug e an ad de dheth
s chunnchunnaic i gun rorobh te dha na cluas cluasan ga dhidhith
s ghaghabh i eageagal mor ach lean i e cha rorobh feum
dhi tiltilleadh Rainig e an ru rubha s fhaid fhaide muimuigh an Li
ChaChaidh i sios ri taotaobh a chladchladaich agu gus an d rainig
s uamh s chaichaidh i staistaigh Bha eār eathar eir a
tar tarraing gu bial na h-uamh. Bha sin san uamh
na shinshineadh eir seiche na ba ghoghobha fear mo ghua ghraidh
agus cailcailleach mhor ghlas na suisuidhe taotaobh nan teine
Thainig uthu ars a chailchailleach Thainig ars esan. Gu de
An te tha leat an so. Tha nan te bha mi sirsireadh.
Dean biabiadh dhomh ars am fear so ris a chailchaillich
gur gruam gruam gruamach gruamach sinn eir barn bairnich fad sac sinn eir chairis charghais Ni mismise sin ach cha
nil bia biadh deas gus an dean mi e. Theid mi an
uisge ars a chailchailleach. Cha teid ars ninighean ghoghobha s mi
fhifhin odag ach dh falfhalbh a chailchailleach agus tugthug ninighean ghoghobha
chailchailleach gu bun aineaibhne far an rorobh uisge stad. Chrom
a chailchailleach gu rug ruig n an uisge. Chrom ninighean ghoghobha agus
chuir i chailchailleach fon uisge gus na bhabhath i i. Theich
agus thug i h-aghh-aghaidh eir Cairnish. Nuair rainig i CairCairinis
bha traitraigh na faolfaoghal ann agus ghaghabh i n traitraigh Rainig i
Bailevanaich agus ghaghabh i gu bubuth agus cheancheannaich
i deise friagh bhriagh s ghaghabh i gu aite diomhair
agus chuir i uimpe i. GhaGhabh i eir aghaghaidh agus chachaidh
i far faothail Chreagorry. ChaChaidh i ron CheanCheann
Deas gus na raigrainig i tao Loch baoghastaibaoghastail gu
taitaigh bodachain bhig. Dh fhainfhaighnich am bodbodach co as a
thaigthainig i. Thuirt i nach rorobh innt ach seolseoladair bha sir sireadh
son saothach soitheach. An ta bha mise g iasgiasgach an
raoir agus bha saosaothach san Loch gusagus bha n sgiobsgiobair ag
rath gun rorobh lamh a dhidhith eir. Bha i an oicheoidhche
sin an taitaigh a' bhodbhodachain san lairna mhairmhaireach chaidh i le eareathar big
beag bha aige gu taotaobh an t saothsaothaich agus ghaghabh i fo
fasdadh aig an sgiopsgiobair. Cha dean deanadh i car
tuar ris an sgiobsgiobair gus am faic faiceadh i gu de
br fhiach i. Thuirt i nach rorobh i riariamh eir saoth
ach gu rorobh i eoleolach eir eareathar An ceanceann a mhios
cha rorobh lamh eir bodbord cho math ririthe Chuir a sin
an sgiobsgiobair muin muinntireas blian bliadhna orra oirre agus thug e £30 di dhi
thug i leis blian bliadhna aige. Dar a reachreachadh iad gu port
bheir na lamh lamhan eile gu ol s gu ruideireacruideireachd
orr ach bha ise fuirfuireach eir bord. Bha an sgiobsgiobair deondeonach
fasdfasdadh eile chur orr oirre ach so cha deandeanadh i. Bha an
sgiopsgiobair dol eir son lucluchd sgod an taotaobh tuatuath agus
chuir e ise eir tir an Loch baoghastail.
ChaiChaidh i gu taitaigh gobhgobha am Baoghastail
Dh' fhiosDh' fhiosraich an gobhgobha co s as thainig i. Dh innis i gur
gille seolseoladair i bha sir sireadh coscosnadh Chan eil coscosnadh agam
dhut ach tha gille dhidhith orm sa cheardcheardaich agus
mu ghaasghabhas tu agam bheir mi ob.obair duit.
GhaGhabh i so fasdfasdadh blianbliadhna aige ghobha s mun rorobh i mios ann cha rorobh gille
riariamh aig aige cho mamath ririthe. S mun taingtainig ceann na
blianbliadhna b fearrfhearr i nan gogobha fhein Bha aon
nieannighean aig a ghoghobha do chunnaig bho dhuine agus
de ach ghaghabh i gaol eir a ghoghobha og. Bha easeasan a
fuirfuireach ta uaipe. De ach a chailchailleadh iuch iuchair Chille
bhride agus chuir chuireadh fios eir a ghoghobha gus na
glasun a thog thogail agus iuch iuchair ur a dheandheanamh. ChaiChaidh
fios a chur thun ghoghobha agus chaichaidh i Chill Chille Bhride agus thog e
na glas glasan agus thug e dachdachaidh iad ann am poca.
Bha nan gobha nion nighean choimh a' coimhead eir na glas glasan agus
mar bu mhumhutha comh a choimhead e orra sann bu mhumhutha eagal nach
tig tigeadh dilin an sa dhean dheanadh e iuch iuchair ur dhaibh. Tha mismise ors
eise faigh faighinn mo loin gu math eir fear Chill bhride
agus mur chailleas mi a chairdcheaird is beag is d fhiach
mi obair. Cha tig dil an la is urran urrainn mis iuch iuchair a dhe dheanamh>
dha na glas glasan so. Hud ni sibh gun teagteagamh ors an gille-ni nighean
cha dean ors an gille gobgobha bha glas na dha nam
measg gan dean deanainn iuch iuchair ach cha dearg mi eir a
chuid mhor dhiu. Gu dearbh dearg deargaidh ars an gille-
Na bi smalan no lium leann dudubh eir – ni sibh iad
ach sibsibh ga fhiach fhiachainn cha chreid mi fhein nach
dean deanadh tu fhefhein iad ars an gogobha. U cha dean chan
eil sin coltach gun dean deanainn iad ach fiach fiachaidh mi
sin agus dun sibh don chon na ceard ceardaich moch sa
mhadmhadainn s cha leig sin sinn neach a stigh ach sin sinn
fhein SanSann mar so bha gle mhoch sa mhadmhaduinn
bha gille ghobhghobha eir a chois agus fhuair a pluc
taois o bhean a ghobh.gobha as is rinrinn e sudsiud ris na glas glasan
agus thoisthoisich e sin agus mun tainig an oichoidhche
bha glasiuchiuchair aig cuseir gach glais. Ma Math rud
ghille as arsa an gogobha Moire s tu s an ann agd agad tha
lamhin lamhan a ghobhghobha s chan ann agam ged
a their iad gogobha ma math rium. Theid uthu dhachdhachaidh led
niannighean agus cuir cuiridh tu na glas glasan mar bha idiad
roimhe. U cha teid – reachreachaibh fhefhein leo. Cha
teid nach mor an cliu dhomhs gum bi
gille agam. Ma their Fear Baghastail
gu bheil usathusa ma mathc their e ach se tha
ma math n an gogobha fhein mar ma tha leid leithid so ghille
aig aige. Chuir an gogobha an gille Chill Chille Bride ga am
loin leis na glas glasan gan cur. Dh falbhfhalbh e leo
ann am poc gle mhocmhoch sa mhadmhadainn agus
mun taing tainig meanmeadhan lalatha cha rorobh glas nach rorobh crute cruthaichte
Bha aan gille nist air son falfalbh dachdachaidh ach cha leig
Fear Bh.Bhoghastail leis. U feumfeumaidh mi tiltilleadh gun dail agus
a bhibhith dachdachaidh a nocnochd. Cha teid uthu dachdachaidh nocnochd ion
U theid chan eil anns ach sin agus cha fhreagfhreagair
e domhdhomh bhibhith fuifuireach eir falbh o obair mo mhaghmhaighstir U
cha teid mas e 'n gobhgobha do mhaighmhaighstir s mis maighmaighstir
a ghobhgobha agus cha teid uthu dachdachaidh nocnochd s cha teid uthu
dachdachaidh mairmaireach U cha nchan fhadfhaod sin bhibhith mar sin
ler cead – chan eil m uine mach s chan eil
e freagfreagairt domhdhomh m aonta bhrist.bhristeadh agus droch cliu chliu
a chos.chosnaich domhdhomh fhein. Bha 'n gille cordcordadh ri FFear BhBhaghastail cho
math s nach diu gu eir e dh-faladh'fhalbh agus chum
e 'n tainig e agus chuir e fios thun a ghoghobha mar so.
Mu bha 'n gogobha duilich agus se bha duil duilich s bha aor
aige s e bha duil duilich a ninighean s i call a fuilt lisleis
a ghaol bha aice eir ghille. Bha i chun a bhibhith marbh
leis an dorran nach do chuir i n ceill don
ghille fad sa an coramcothrom aicaice ach bha i beo an dochdochas
ma gugum faifaigheadh coramcothrom fhastfhathast. Bha an gille teichteicheadh bho ninnighean
a ghoghobha chionn cha rorobh cocothrom a gheogheobhadh i nach rorobh i na
chuid chuideachd s na chora chomhradh s i an deoin a cri cridhe eir. Bha niannighean
ghoghobha saoilsaoilsinn gur h ann bha i teichteicheadh uaipe chionchionn gur
ghill ghille apar i agus sansann mar so bu ra ghaol ghaolach i eir
Bha nist an gille am FFear BhBhaghastail agus bha e na phage aige
fhin agus bha e cordcordadh ris fuasfuathasach fuasfuathasach mamath. Bha
an gille na ghill ro ghrinn s cho moghmodhail s cho
tur turail toinisgeil s gun ghaghabh FFear BBhoghastail speis mhor de dheth agus
bha e leis gach taotaobh a reachreachadh e nach bibiodh an gille na
chois. Thainig a sin brairbrathair na baintiarnabiantighearna gam faicfaicinn agus nua nuair
bhi bhiodh FFear BBhaghastail agus an duin tuasalt-uasal og so mach a
seagsealg bhi bhiodh am page daondaonnan co comhla riu riutha. Bha am page na fhear
cuideaccuideachd anabaranabarrach taitneach agus bha e toirt moran
spors do na h-uaislean agus bha moit mhor eir
FFear BBhaghastail a leud leithid do phage sgiamh sgiamhach aoidh aoidheil abhaireach abharsach
bhi bhith aige agus n an tratrath thill iad dachdachaidh as a bheinn sheilg
bu ghnaghnath leoleotha bhi ri seanseanchas do'n bhantbhantighearna mu dheidheidhinn seanseanchas
agus spors a phage. Se bh an ann gun rorobh mor moran dei deidh aig
a bhaintbhaintighearna i fhein a dh faighfhaighinn lalatha do'n phage feuch
am faigh faigheadh i spors leis mar chacha agus fhuair i
so. LaLatha bha sin an tratrath chaichaidh FFear BBhaghastail agus a bhrabhrathair ceile an
bheinbheinn sheilg dh fagfhag iad am page aig an taitaigh chum
coraicomhraidh agus conaltraiconaltraidh chum chumail ris a bhaintbhaintighearna. Nuair
a dh-eirich a bhaintbhaintighearna agus bha i dol ghailghabhaila braicfast chuir
i fios eir a phage agus thainig e. Shir i eir sui suidhe sios
agus a bhracbhracaist a ghailghabhail co comhla ri rithe. U cha sui suidh chan eil sin coltcoltach
gun suisuidhinn sios gu m bhiabhiadh co comhla ruibhse agus a
bharbharrachd eir a sin ghaghabh mise mo bhraicbhraicfast mar tha. Ni
u thu suisuidhe co dhiu ars ise agus feumfeumaidh tu suidesuidhe agus le
naire tintighinn an aghaghaidh na baintbaintighearna shuidh am page a
sios aig a bhord agus ghaghabh e greim bithe maille rithe. Nuair a ghaghabh iad am
braicbracaist chaichaidh a bhaintbhaintighearna null an leableabaidh agus thuirt i ris a
phage Thig a nall gu treis conaltraiconaltraidh agus spors us abh abhachdas
co comhla rim rium. Cha teid cha teid ars ma page. Gu de ni
eir bi bith a ni mi chan dean mi sin agus FFear BBhaghastail gun
bhi bhith aig baile. &c Thig uthu led dh d-aineoin mar tig uthu led
dheoin ars ise agus i leum a nall as an leab leabaidh agus
a bre breith eir a phage ga thoir dhan leableabaidh. Ach a sin
cha reachreachadh am p page agus thoithoisich iad ri gleic gleac – eise sirsireadh
a mach agus ise ga chuir is taitaigh. Chuir i nan cloi'einclaidhean
air an dorus agus a mach chan fhaifaigheadh am page agus
ise g eubhach aird a claiginclaiginn. Thainig na searbhsearbhantan uile na
rui ruith feuch gu de bha cearr agus fhuair iad a bhainbhaintighearna ion
sa bhi marbh eir an urlar agus a h aodaodann eir a reubreubadh s eir
a strac sracadh aig a phage nam b fhior. Rug Rugadh eir a bhainbhaintighearna agus thog thogadh
a lai laigh i agus rugadh eir a phPhage agus chuir chuireadh an toll dudubh e. S anS ann mar
so bha nuair thainig FFear BBhaghastail dhachdhachaidh as a bheinbheinn sheilg fhuafhuair
e bhainbhaintighearna na lailaigh gun duil ri rithe agus am page am priosan.
Dhin Dh'innis a bhaintbhaintighearna an t aobhadhbhar dha fhin agus gu brabrathair ceile agus
mam b fhior i nach rorobh ni aic aice ach am bris – mar a bhris
sa mhill am page i agus an oillt a chuir e orra oirre. Chuir
FFear BBhaghastail fios eir na searbsearbhantan uile agus cheascheasnaich e iad agus thug iad
fianuis mar chunchunnaic iad. Se bh'ann thug thugadh binn bais
eir a phage a mach chionn droch lamh thoirt eir
baintbaintighearna BhaoghasBhaghasdail agus bha e ri a losgadh gus am bi biodh e
na luailuaithe agus a lualuaithe a leigleigeil ri gaoigaoith. An ceann tri
la'nnlaithean dhordh'ordaich FFear BBhoghastail teine chur ri cruaich mhoir mho mhonadh
agus am page thoirt a mach agus chuir na meanmeadhan Nuair
a ghaghabh an teine mor so thug thugadh a mach am page nach
tuirt gu guth gus a so ach nach rorobh e ciontciontach. Nuair thug thugadh a
mach am page gus a chuir san teine dh-iardh'iarr e
facal do FFhear BBhaghastail agus fhuair e so. Nist ars am page tha
sibh dol gam chur so gu bas – dol gam losglosgadh gu luiluith
s dol a chur mo a leigelleigeil mo lualuath le gaoigaoith.

Mac Righ Eirinn
Bho LachLachlann DonullachDomhnallach Gramesdale 28/10 1870

Bha ririgh eir Eirinn uair agus bha bean us mac
aigaige. ChaochChaochail a bhean agus phos e ristrithist. Bha BhrBhan-righinn
fior olc da a dalt agus dh falbhfhalbh mac an ririgh agus
chaichaidh e far an rorobh sheanair athair a mhatmhathar,
agus chasaid e ris. Bhuil arsa a sheansheanair bheir
mise dhuit culaiculaidh phort agus nuarnuair bha e
falbh sa mhadmhadainn thug a sheansheanair da loth agus
thuirt e ris Nist muma bhisbhios eis no ainisainnis ort
abair ris an loth Crath crath a lothag
agus crathaicrathaidh an loth as an dara cliaichcliathach
sad oir agus as a chleaichchliathach eile sad
airgid. Dh falbhfhalbh e leis an loloth agus nuair bha
e air an astar smaoinsmaoinich e gun taoghaltadhaileadh
e choimeadchoimhead a mhuimmhuime agus gun cuircuireadh
e seachseachad cuid na h-oicheh-oidhche leleatha. Rinn e so
Thuirt e ra mhuimmhime Nist a mhuirn
eag chan abair uthu crath crath a loaglothag
Chan abaabair a ghaoil s mi nach ababair. Coma
co dhiu nuair chachaidh mac an ririgh a laigh thuitthuirt
a mhuimmhuime CraCradh cracrath a loaglothag agus thuit sad
oir as an dala taotaobh agus sad airgairgid as an
taotaobh eile. Chum a mhuinmhuime an lorlotharagus
thug i dha loloth eile. Nuair bha e falfalbh thuirt e
aghaghaidh e eir an astaastar CraCrath cracrath a loaglothag ach cha tigtigeadh
sian as an loloth Thill e far an rorobh sheansheanair agus
thuirt e nach tigtigeadh sian a taotaobh na loloth Coma
leat co dhiu bheir mise dhuit brath agus
nuair bhios eis no ainisainnis ort their uthu Beil
beil a bhra agus tuittuitidh min chruachruaidh chorcchoirce as
an dara taotaobh agus flur geal cruinneaccruithneachd as an taotaobh eile
ThaoghThug e so leis a so aig a mhuimmhuime agus an
an am dol a chadchadal chuir e na h-earh-earail i nach
abradh i Beil beil a bhrabhrath U chan ab.abair
a ghaoil ach nuair a chaichaidh easeasan a lailaigh thuitthuirt
An tratrath dh falafhalbh eise eir an astar thuirt
e Beil beil a bhra cahach cha tigtigeadh ni aiste
Thug i Chuir i bra eile na h-aite so. Thill
e thun a sheansheanair Coma leatsa bheir mise
dhuit rud mus bhios tu fhefhein glic a ni sin
a fhastfhathast agus nuair bha e falbh thug e dha
ialiall agus plocan agus their uthu nuair thig
cruas no cas ort CeailCeangail ceailceangail ialiall stialstiall
stialstiall a phlocain. ChaiChaidh e leis a so thun
taitaigh a mhuimmhuime agus thug e cail orraoirre FeadFeadh
na h-oicheh-oidhche chuala e glaodh us sgrailsgraill nach
cualcuala i riariamh agus dh-eirich e De bha so ach
chuil duine stistigh an deideidh an cealceangal agus
a chailchailleach eir an ceanceann agus am plocan
gan stialstialladh. O ghraighraidh ors a mhuimmhuimes cuicuir
stad air a so. CuiCuir muma bheir usathusa domhdhomh
mo loloth agus mo bhra agus thug i dha so gu
toil.toileach agus dh falfhalbh e agus dheandheanadh an loloth agus
a bhra gach sian mar a ghealgheall a sheansheanair
agus dh fasfhas mac an ririgh fuasfuathasach beirtbeairteach agus
cha deach e riariamh tuillituillidh a choir a sheansheanair no
mhuime. So crioch na sgialsgialachd.

Bha mac righ fo gheasaibh agus bhitheadh
e na each uisge san oicheoidhche agus na shi-
each san lalatha. Bha sin nieannighean tuaanaichtuathanaich
a muigh ri crodh agus thuit i na cadal
agus bhiodh an t each uisge tintighinn ga comhcomhail.
Fas nieannighean an tuatuathanaich letromachleatromach agus beir
mac. Bha moran teumail eir a cairdcairdean
agus orra fhein agus chaichaidh far i far an robh
sean duine agus dh inisinnis e dhi gur h-e ar
sisitheach a rinrinn so oir cha rorobh sian fios co mhill
an niannighean Thuirt e rierithe chuir an lein ri
taotaobh na buaile agus e dhol fo scur falaich
ChaiChaidh i so agus so mar a chuala i an
sieachsitheach a seinn dhan leanleanabh
Tha n ceo sa bheinn bhan ceo sa bheinn
bheirinn dhut or bheirbheirinn dhut or
S gu leoir a bheirteas ach
bheir dhut fian bheir dhut fian
S gach ni a b aite leat ach nach cuircuirinn leat sa mhat
Nuair a bha n leanleanabh mic tri bliannabliadhna
thainig mac an righ as na geasaibh agus
phos e nieannighean an tuaanachtuathanaich. Cha rorobh e ri faigh
inn as na geasgeasaibh gus am faigh e mar ri te na
cadai nieannighean bha e na each usg uisge.
div.add:
From Mrs MacDonald
Gramasdale
Friday night 28/10 1870

div.p:
Craonieval – Leab a mhiosachain on
the N.North W.West shoulder of hill halfway up. A circle
Rough diagram within which seems underground runs
now covered over with stonystoney earth. In centcentre
a cist & at end of the Leab is another. About 12 ydsyards
on lower side outside mark a big stone
standing.
Glut, Pit hollow. Glutlionadh, packing in building wall.

Cailleach Luirsag
From Donald Mac

The Macaulays are descddescended from MAuladh
dearg Mac RiRigh Lochlain. AulAuladh dearg had
the outer Hebrides. Clann ic 'Illemhoire
from Ireland. Clann ic carmaig frfrom Carm
aig mac RiRigh LochLochlain. Clann ic Thorudail frfrom
LochlLochlan & also Clann AonaisAonghais frfrom AonasAonghas
mac RiRigh LochLochlain. Clann ic Ruisig from one of
the 20 men soldiers who came with TochraTochradh ninnighean
a Chaanaich.

MacColla, Alastair. The Campbells were collcollected
when the young chief came into the propproperty & he was givgiven
there a cuirm. The young chief asked the landlord if there
was any perperson in to send them with him to spend the night
The LandLandlord said there was only one gentleman Tell
him to come said uacaranuachdaran nan CaimbCaimbeulach.
The LandLandlord did so & the gentgentleman refused. So the young
chief sent him again & again & the third time
he accaccepted (Clann ic Caoilte an old race
in N.North Uist. none now.) The young Campbell
placed the stranger oppopposite himself. In the course
of conconversation the young CampCampbell asked the strangstranger his name. I am a Macdonald. S mor na fiachein bha againagainn eir
na DonulaichDomhnullaich said a forforward yngyoung man present. Mac
DonMacDonald made no reply. The yngyoung man reptrepeated his remremark
& the 3 time MacDonMacDonald asked what were the debts. Tha
ga nam bith ann ach na chosg sin de chamh
ga'n crochadh aig DunabheartaiDunabheartaidh said the
for.forward Campbell. Ma thiondais tu'n taotaobh eile an
duil.duilleag said MacDonMacDonald chi gu daor a phaiphaigh sin
a chainb sin leis na chaill chosg sin do
lannan ris na CaimbCaimbeulaich gan cur le LochaiLochaidh.
He stood up & took hold of the two fronts of his cot
coatacota mor & threw all the buttons out in a shower &
brotbroughtout the sword. The young Campbell tried to pacify
him but to no purpose He then asked him why
he drew his sword. MacDonMacDonald repreplied that he did so
to pick him off the geug. The landlandlord rushed in spread
a towel of bread & cheese with which he met him on the
doorsteps & asked him who he was. Is fear mi
dha'n chinne mhor 's dh'an phor mhiart
anach. Alastair MacColl was under coill at
the time & it was thought this was him.

It was MacLeod of Talaisgeir who shot Sir
James in the bonn dughdubh

Cumha
From Mr Ranald Macdonald Taransay Harris
at Truimisgearry Monday night 21, NovrNovember 1870

lg.l: Mi m aonar an cluain a bharraich

Dhomhsa b aineaithne beus do bhaile
Feasgar fuaill faoilifaoilidh earraich
Muc ga sgriopasgriobadh mart ga feanadhfeannadh
IteadhItheadh iad uile dha'n coradh
Tha mo theanga fallain conarstcomhnard
ChaiChaidh i eir ghleus eir a mhoindebhon-de
Tha tri raoin us faobhar leois orraoirre
Cha be bais mo thiarnthighearna oig e

div.p:
Teampul na Trianaid Carnish
From John Mac Innonkinnon Carnish WednsWednesday 18/1 1871

Teample built 767 a 772 ago by NinNighean
Mhic DhuilDhughail LatharnLatharna who had much riches
& went about building in diftdifferent placplaces & so learleft
a name behind her. The reciter said bits of
charmed wood on the top of the walls. Wr
burnt & all in ScotScotland in one night the reason reason of the burning a dead secret. The peoppeople of BenBenbecula
& SSouth Uist were wont to come & take the grass
on the temple for cures the same of the walls
of Tobar na Trianaid. They always left
coins of some sort as pay of the water.
There were 3 X. A x mhor & 3 x beaga
The people went round 3 times deseil on
the x beaga ere they went to Bhuain an fheor
or take awaaway the water. Remembers this & when
the stones that supsupported the x were up. A DonDonald Mac
donald crofter took the stones that supsupported the
crosses & built his houses with them after
which his mothmother went deranged his wife
lost her lūs his cattle & horse went all wrong
some of his childchildren died & everything went wrong
with him aftafter which he went to Canada
where he got on for a time & made some
money & sold his land. In a few nights aftafter
he was robbed. He then got on again &
the whole of his houses & stock were
burnt. He is now getting on again. DonlDomhnull
mac ic Ruari DhonilDhomhnuill ic Dhonil ic Ruari
RembsRemembers a lots of images in the EEast end in
side. Fuamhaire mor an Teampu
ill was sunk in the wall little bit
above the rest. 3 heads used to fritenfrighten people
for its appappearance. TeampTeampuill Chlann a Phiocair
on NNorth side. These peoppeople took sealbh on it
& stuck to it. Built long long aftafter the
temple. Built at the expenexpense of the RomRoman
CathCatholic Church. The Teampul mor
was all that nieannighean mhic DhuilDhughaill
built. Built for TaiTaigh Chailleacha Dubha

Mac DhonilDhomhnuill DuiDuibh who was superior
lived in a house abtabout 200 ydsyards west of the Temple.
HectHector saw the ruins of his house. He & his
wife lived togtogether & no family no cattle. He then
got ill & evyevery morning a bo mhaol bhin
came to his door to be milked & when the wife milked
her she went away & nothing was seen of her
till she came at dusk. No one knew
where the cow came frfrom nor where she went
She was one of the crocrodh mara. There is
an isle between Ronay & Eval caledcalled
EilEilean na ba maoile Buie from & here
the cow went to & came from to be milked
One day while milkmilking her the cow moved & the
woman spilt the milk. Gu ma h-olc
dhuit said the woman to the cow. O said
the man s tu thuirt gu dona. – Cha tig a
bho tuille & as the man got well the
cow never came again

The Macdonalds are said never to
have prospered when the nuns had been
(I know one who does prosper) Nunton. Tis
said there is CroCrodh mara. There was but onone
house in LmaddyLochmaddy – a fisherman who lived
where the Sponish – on the point. The
fishfisherman used to see cows in the isle & he went
to them & found there the crocrodh mara & his cof
mit he saw their udders full of milk
& his wife went to milk them & did so & made
butter & cheese for ½ yryear.

A hero of Clanranald lived at Roisinis
& had 1 cow & but little milk. One morngmorning his
wife saw 3 crocrodh maol buibuidhe & went to milk
them. A voice came to her at night & requestrequested
her to spill some the full of the cuman
on the top of the sithein (Roisinis)
She did so each day & ever aftafter she had
the cows & plenty of milk. When the woman
died the cows left & never retdreturned.

It was a man Flags were in the foundfoundations
of the temple & persons dug away to get at
these at the west end where the gable fell
The gable lay that way for a long time till one
Uilleam Clachair (?PatersonPatterson) from
Assaint a TuaTuath came here to work
at Balranald aftafter which he went to work
at Nunton aftafter which he came to live
at Carnish. He saved some money and
having a notion for antiqantiquities he began and
built up the gable to the level of the sides
The staging fell & 1 man was killed & 2 hurt
so the man went no farthfarther with his patri
otic work. UillUilleam ClachClachair went to CaralinaCarolina
where he got the propproperty of a piper & he kildkilled him
self with the pipe. CrocCnoc na piocair
is on the NNorth side of temple.

Only 2 windows in temple – 1 on eaeach side of
one anothanother One of these still seen on. The
north side just the same 2 doors opopposite
one another like each othother Arches of carved
freestone There was a tower much higher
than the gable. RembsRemembers the gable up on EEast end
puttgputting enter Nuns left it for Nunton & Nun
ton for Heisgeir Tobar na TrianTrianaid was
around – heard it. Knows it. Must open it
Loch na Trianaid south of the Temple now
a bog. (Gleanna mine Moristean

Far nach icheadh na coin na coillean
– coillean giubhais – friamaichean)
Nuns were also at Kirkibost.
NieanNighean Mhic DhuilDhughail built TeampTeampuill Mhicheil
while waitwaiting porst = upon one oceans
Dunan NieanNighean an Armain in Bagh
mor Carnish close to Eilean a chomhraig
Where leavgleaving aftafter building of the finfinished Temple
the work people are said to have thrown a
stone each in a big heap. Tis large heaps
over a round rock. Now a good deal
scattered.

Twas one Mac Coiseam a tuanachtuathanach at
CarCarinish who built the west end & not
not "UillUilleam Clachair" who built a teampteampuill
beag on the S.South side. There is a sgeir
ioc Coiseam N.North W.West N. end of of TeampTeampuill
– N.North of Horay named after the man. He
thought Lord Macdonald – am Moraire
would pay at least part of his expenseexpenses & when he
fodfound that he would not he relinquished the work.
There was one woman in middle of the 8 gables
The windwindow on the SSouth side was directly oppopposite the passage leading into Caibeal Clann a Phiocair
All the windows arched. The holes seems for scaf
olding in W.West end. The 2 buildbuildings not but alike. The
TempTemple boxed in – Lime takes 300 yrsyears stregenthingstrenghening 300 strong & 300 relaxgrelaxing. Crois an t-sliacaidh
(an t-sleacait-sleacaidh) at Sunamal where the people
frfrom BenBenbecula used to come to view the TempTemple The TempTemple
bubuilt first & then EagEaglais Chalum-chille & then SSaint MichMichael's
NieanNighean Mhic DhuilDhughaill used to send masonmasons to the
gribeachun on the point to make pollagan
sollaidh for fishing for the poor people.
These are still seen.

RaolRaghnall mac AleinAilein was the last who in
habited Caisteal Bhuiri. He added
to the WWest end & added the porch Twas
Iain mhic Uistean ic Dhomhnuil
mhic Dhonuil mac Onail. Twas he
who marmarried nieannighean mhic RaoillRaghnaill ic AilenAilein
who bore him DonulDomhnull (AonasAonghas Alastair The First ministminister of Howmore SSouth UiUist
& Iain(?) A cumhnant was made that
when she died with her body or Mac UistUistein's
head shldshould come to Benbecula. Her
body came BurBuried at Nunton. DonlDomhnull
Breac – His naturnatural son was seen comgcoming
to GrimGriminish & Mac UistUistein Nar cha teid
cloidclogaid cheann lialiath Mhic UistUistein. a
null eir faoilfadhail an diugh (Eir laimh
Mhic Onail nan rorobh e ann an Callar
nish againn cha leiginleiginn sin as ors
Mac UistUistein at the court) This oath
was common in those days. Fag
a lease. DonlDomhnull beag Bhaic was a son
of AlastAlastair mac DhonlDhomhnuill mhic UistUistein
GhrimGhriminish. DonlDomhnull beag was illeillegitimate & son of a
widow who had a large family before
then Ruary Saor says a seal was
kildkilled by a man with a spade EEast of CaistCaisteal
Bhuiri in 1803 by Iain ban mac
AlastAlastair mac DhonachaiDhonnachaidh – a crofter at
Gearra beag, Torlom Biorlain mhic
ic AilAilein used to be anchoranchored in a poll
on east side of the Castle, & long aftafter
childchildren used to swim in that pool
Castle built on a sgeir mhara
Boats used to come to Aird Fhad
in NuntNunton in frfrom Leanacleit & fishing
in the loch na h-Oban Grimgr
Twas for niannighean mhic ic AilAilein who
marmarried mac UistUistein GhrimGhrimnis the who was
cal.called FiongFiongalla that Flora mac Donald
was named. When goggoing to Eain Mac
UistUistein & his illgilligitimate son DonlDomhnull Breac
used to change the poc they carcarried when
they met people – sentservant & master
Mac UistUisitein had no EnglEnglish but his
son plenty. When they ask Mac UistUistein
co b iongiongnadh leis bhibhith tintighinn he said no one
wldwould stop him comgcoming to agagain – his wife
being dead in the house. DonlDomhnull Breac
offoffered his brothbrother if they gave him a share
of his fathers cuid that he woldwould not
allow their mothmother's body to be cardcarried to
BenbBenbecula but they wold not promispromise so he
said that he would get greim ers
fasga fheidsa bhiodh athair seid
agus adsan bhibhith dol le am mairmathair
which they had to do. When Mac UistUistein
came for his wife he had his shoes
in one hadhand his staff in other & his stock
in each pockpocket of jacket & his kilt
Mu gheogheobh mi rucan dosun sin
thall siri mi Ruari Saor is
the 6th & Bal said the 7th glun from
this mac Uistean – from AlastAlastair
Bain son of Mac UistUistein – maternal gl.na
CatrinaCatriona niannighean AlastAlastair bhain frfrom whom
he is. No tacksman frfrom Barra head to CaolCaolas
na h Earadh is from a tacksman who lived
in Ruarys Saors first siol. AonasAonghas Og
AirimhuilAiridh mhuillinn who was drowned at Loch
aoineart in SepSeptember 1805 buried at Bois
dale He was marmarried to a datdaughter of Colin Bois
dale & so he was burdburied along his wife who died
before him. He was ten days ere his body was got
The most lapach man in the boat
was seized by the peintpeinter frfrom the slo vessel
– 3 others drowned.

Places where holes for Soll (soul) are
each side of bun LLoch ephort Ru heva (?) at
BvanaichBailevanaich below Nunton – & out at
the baigh on east side BbeculaBenbecula.

After buildbuilding TempTeampuill na TrianTrianaid, the fuileachfuighleach
was made to build SSaint Michael.

lg.l: Nam bi sa am BealBealach an sgail
Far na thuit an damh donn
Dh ich feoil us dh ol am fuil
Far na mharmharbh an damh donn
S an deacha mo chreach lom fon mhuir

div.p:
Orsa bean Ghilleaspa dhuin niannighean
mhic ic Ailein GillGilleaspu DDubh has no
family. He killed one brobrother in Paible & another
he then went off to see his othother brobrother in DuntuilDuntuilm
How is my brobrother said Mac Onail. Well he is oftoften
buildbuilding a new house. A new house! Well
I am buildbuilding a boat to go to see you in Uist.
So aftafter dindinner the 2 brobrothers went to see the boat. There
is a f bad failing here said GGilleaspu DDubh Mac OnOnail
stooped down to look at this & GGilleaspu DDubh liftlifted
an axe & killed him. GilleGilleaspu DDubh had his house
at Sollas & Ruari Saor remremembered when
the tuatuath pulpulled down the last of it with ropes

Duke of Tarentum a little man 7, 7 or 8
well made. At IocarIochdar a cask which seld
to all the people. (Very like his cousin
Fear Howbig then living. Intended to come
again.

Caisteal Bhuiri. FriFriday 20/1 1871 Lianacleit
Bho EachEachann Macleoid (85) EachEachann mac
DhonilDhomhnaill ic 'UrachaiMhurchaidh ic Neil(1) ic Coin
nich ic Iain ic Ruari ic Thormaid ic Uilleam
ic Thorcail ic Leoid Leothais.
20/1 1871 Friday. Hect'sHector's came si-seansinn-seanair
came with Sine nieannighean mhic Leoid
Leodhais. His name was Niall(1). Mac
ic ic Ailein went for her & her fathfather was
unwilgunwilling to give her so he told him as an excuse
that gun rorobh leum na ceann aig aird na
gealaich. ClanClan Ranald retreturned home & went again
& stole her away – she nothing lothloath. They came
ashashore at Roisinis. MacLeod folfollowed & crossed
the S.Sound of Harris & when he camcame to RoisRoisinis he only
found the biorlinbiorlainn. He set a tar barrel undunder
it & burnt it. ClanClan Ranald who had a fashion of saying
"Mach-ann"? & this they gave him as a
byename. Word was sent to NuntoNunton & the sag
airst-buird – who, the tiarnatighearna GaelGaidhealach keeptkept
a SagSagart buird in those days – & others came
& met them at Guala deas Ruaival
Clan was This was in seacuin-na-
ceusdaseachduinn-na-ceusda in the CarrasCarghas. ClanClan Ranald intinsisted
on the Irish priest who was called an
t athair Calum – to marry them & on
his denyingrefusing told him that he would get
him as good if he were broken. The only
bad thing Sine ninighean Mhic Leoid did
was to quarrel with FathFather Calum & send
him away. I seek said he that no pain
to your souls but sliocsliochd mor eir
bheagan gliocais. Bha so mar so co
dhiu se guiguidhe an t-sagt-sagairt no Sine Nic onaid
na h-onaid. She had 15 childchildren & the only wise
perperson was Miss Peggie who had part of
Ormacleit. Sine was mothmother to Gordon
Ailein. Gordon is burburied in Boisdale &
Peiggie & AilAilein in Cladh Mhoire at Nunton.
Mach-ann was Iain(?) mhic RaoilRaghnaill
who left BorvBorve Castle. (RaolRaghnaill nan tri
RaolRaghnaill tiarntighearna is miasa thig no thainig)
Twas he who lost the island) The reciter HectHector
& Clan randranald are al na h-aona bhliannabliadhna)

Braobh-fhaothal – passed the foot
of a hillock in Lianacleit close to Tolarum
Tis a buryburying placplace & a family – AonasAonghas mac Neil
– DonulDomhnull ain Ruari Shaoir – who lived
there for seven yrsyears. They used to see a ghost
UnbatUnbaptised childchildren were wont to be burdburied in this
placplace – in the Cladh beag – bliannabliadhna na
tathaich was this year of the ghost calldcalled.
They used to see fingers writgwriting in the ashes
coming throthrough deal boards & everything in the hosehouse
topsy turvy. A bare hand with a caman
intin it was seen comgcoming out throthrough – only 3 fingers
The caman was thrown into the sea & when
the man retreturned the caman was in before him.
This was abt 47 ysyears ago.

Last Autumn at IocarIochdar a man headheard a
ranrann leinibh outside & thinkthinking it was a
little gull he sent a message he went
out to see. He saw a womwoman with a child
in her arms. She spoke & he spoke see
the dautdaughter of the King of France said she
Thuit mi ann an diolanas
thy path was not for my doing – eir
a shon domh. He sent me to the Eilean
an Iar a so. I came to SSouth Uist first
I did not like it & went to N.North Uist. But
while crossing the ford the obair chloinechloinne
came upon me at Heastainal Isle
I made for Teastamal but fell in tiura
an lain & I bore a c my child & we both died
there. The tide brotbrought me down but my child
was found & it was burdburied in Cladh breagbeag
Braobh-fhathail. The man who was
there destrydestroyed the repose of the child (–AonasAonghas

Bean Nithidh – A man in Sgir Mhionganish in
Skye (?Ruandunain) met the bean-nithe agus
she gave him a gri'eagaggritheagag and told him that as
long as he kept that he would be sona but that the
day he lost it would be the begin of this miseries.

The gri'eagaggritheagag was to be his charm throthrough life
one Sunday when he went to church his brother put
on his wearing vest. He accidentally discovered
carefully sown up in a corner of the vest a
small gritheagag. He held it on the palm
of his hand after he disinterred it frfrom its hiding
comcompartment and was looking at it intensely. He raisdraised
his head to look at something else for a momoment
& when he brotbrought back his eyes to the palm of his
hand the gri'eagaggritheagag was gone. He searched the
spot upon which he was standing but not with
all his searching failed to find the gri eagaggritheagag. He
went home & put off the vest & said nothing. When the brobrother
returned frfrom church he went to his vest &
searched for the grigan. He askdasked his brobrother who
acknowdacknowledged that he lost it The mans misfor
tunes began & disaster folfollowed disdisaster. He then took ill
& it was on his deathbed a day or two ere he died he told his brother how
he obtained the grigan frfrom the fairy(?) and
all it about it. The brobrother told George Stoddart
sheep manager Newton NNorth Uist.

Carnish Temple Alx.Alexander Macdonald
AlastAlastair na h-ainne CladCladdach Kirkibost says
that he saw the east gable of the temple falling
One day the Dall mor was holding a
meeting there. He (AlexAlexander MacdonMacdonald) was sittgsitting by
him when he saw a small bit of lime the
size of whelk (faochag) fall frfrom the top. Some
thing struck him that the gable was going to fall
& he whispered his fears to the Dall Mor. All
the people rose & left the spot. They had hardly
done so when the gable fell with a terrterrifying crash!
No windows on east gable or end.
Not a breath of wind

When the Moraire Ban and his wife
& 3 childchildren & factor Kingsburgh came to Uist to The
family lived at Sollas partly. They went round
& when they reacreached Bailemhartain they found a man
ploughploughing with two horses & 2 cows all of which were mere
skeletons. KinsgKingsborough told the man that Lady Mcdonald
had come among her Uist tenantry for assistassistance to enable
her to educate her child & that she expextexpected 5/- frfrom each
crofter. The crofter told him that there were only £3 of money in the
whole of Uist & that this was sent from one man to another
mentgmentioning the diftdifferent perperson who had the use of it an where
it was lying there. Lady MacMacdonald wept & said that she
could not ask money of people so poor. KinsgKingsborough
then asked the man if they would make kelp. The
man asked what that was. KinsgKingsborough told him & that
there was plenty of gold on the shores & rocks of
Lochmaddy that they wldwould get £1 a ton for the kelp
& that Lady MacDonMacDonald would have 5/- profit
out of this & that he wld send them min gheal chor
A vessel with 12 Irishmen then came to LmaddyLochmaddy
& began kelpkelping. The peoppeople on the west side heard this & they
flocked to LmaddyLochmaddy to see the operoperation The Irish
had the kelp kilns in full operation. The 12 men
went to the sea to fetch buckets of water which they
threw into the kilns. They then progged the burning
kelp with their long oak cabers expecting
thereby to burn &frighten the Uist people. The
burning kelp flew out in all directsdirections & burnt most
severally 11 of the Irish men & all the Uist peoppeople
escaped injuries. One Irish man alone remdremained
to carry his compcompanionss to the smack where they lay
a long time at deaths door. And so this was the begbeginning
of kelp making in NNorth Uist. See page 111 or 112

Dun Chalavy &c
A scion of the lived at Dun
Chalavy Lochboisdale and a scion of the Barra
family lived at Many attempts
were made to get hold of these for they lived upon
robbery & creachs. Macneil was told often that his
friend on Dunchalavy was caught but he would
not believe it. He would alwysalways ask what was got in
his dun. So & so upon one oc.occasion he asked this & was told
that a groat of coppers & a seann saigh mhial
choin was all that was got. Ghlacadh thu gun
teagateagamh said he & it is therefore time for me to make
for myself & he vanished.

Macneil was "wanted" on actaccount of some crime &
Boisdale (?) attemptattempts of to catch him often but failed. He then
went out in a boat with women as if they had
been for heather – all the men lying on the
bottom of the boat under the heather & the womwomen
rowing. As Boisdale(?) anticipated MacNeil jumped
into the the trap when BoisBoisdale & his men started up &
caught him. When they landed about Kilbride
Macneil managed to escape. His foes started
in pursuit & when passing throthrough Gearrynamoine
a man seeing his tiernatighearna in hot pursuit the
threw an arrow & killed Macneil. He was buried
where he fell. While making a drain some
years ago a skeleton was found. Old Ranald
Macdonald told whose skeleton it was & that it was
about there that MacNeil was buried.
